blocks.string: Origin of Jainism

children.string:
‚ñ™Ô∏è   Mahavira was the last 24th Tirthankara.
‚ñ™Ô∏è   He was born at Kundagrama near Vaisali.
‚ñ™Ô∏è   His parents were Kshatriyas. 
Father ‚Äì Siddhartha (Head of Jnatrika Clan); 
Mother ‚Äì Trishala (Sister of Lichchhavi chief Chetaka). 
‚ñ™Ô∏è   He was married to Yasoda and had a daughter Anojja or Priyadarsana.

‚ñ™Ô∏è  At the age of 30, Vardhaman renounced his home and became a wandering ascetic.
‚ñ™Ô∏è  He also observed self-mortification.
‚ñ™Ô∏è  After 13 years of penance, he attained the highest spiritual knowledge called Kevala Jnan. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è  He attained this at Jimbhikagrama village under a sal tree aged 42. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è  This is called **Kaivalya**. Thereafter, he was called Mahavira, Jina, Jitendriya (one who conquered his senses), Nigrantha (free from all bonds), and Kevalin.
‚ñ™Ô∏è  He preached his teachings for 30 years and died at Pava (near Rajagriha) aged 72.

blocks.string: Vardhaman Mahavira¬†(540 ‚Äì 468 B.C.)

children.string:
‚ñ™Ô∏è  Vedic religion had become highly ritualistic.
‚ñ™Ô∏è  Jainism was taught in local Prakrit language thus was more accessible to the common man as compared to Sanskrit.
‚ñ™Ô∏è  It was accessible to people of all castes.
‚ñ™Ô∏è  Varna system had rigidified and people of the lower castes led miserable lives. Jainism offered them an honourable place.
‚ñ™Ô∏è  About 200 years after the death of Mahavira, a great famine in the Ganga valley prompted Chandragupta Maurya and Bhadrabahu (last Acharya of the undivided Jain sangha) to migrate to Karnataka. Jainism spread to Southern India after that.

blocks.string: Causes of the rise of Jainism

children.string:
‚ñ™Ô∏è  Mahavira rejected Vedic principles.
‚ñ™Ô∏è  He did not believe in God‚Äôs existence. According to him, the universe is a product of the natural phenomenon of cause and effect.
‚ñ™Ô∏è  He believed in Karma and transmigration of the soul. The body dies but the soul does not. One will be punished or rewarded as per one‚Äôs karma.
‚ñ™Ô∏è  Advocated a life of austerity and non-violence. Stressed on equality but did not reject the caste system, unlike Buddhism. But he also said that man may be ‚Äògood‚Äô or ‚Äòbad‚Äô as per his actions and not birth.
‚ñ™Ô∏è   Asceticism was taken to a great length. Starvation, nudity, and self-mortification were expounded.
Two elements of the world: Jiva (conscious) and Atma (unconscious):

The **Triratnas** (Three Jewels) of Jainism are fundamental principles that guide practitioners on the path to liberation. They are:
1. Right faith: This includes recognizing the nature of the soul, the reality of karma, and the teachings of the Tirthankaras
2. Right knowledge:  knowledge of Jain teachings, scriptures, and philosophy
3. Right conduct: observance of five vows of jainsim

Right conduct (observance of five vows) of jainism are:
1. Ahimsa (non-violence)
2. Satya (truth)
3. Asteya (no stealing)
4. Aparigraha (no acquiring property)
5. Brahmacharya (abstinence)

blocks.string: Teachings of Jainism

children.string:
After the death of Mahavira, Jainism continued to grow, but around the 3rd century BCE, a major famine in the Ganga valley led to a significant event in Jain history.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Acharya Bhadrabahu, a respected Jain monk, led a group of followers, including Maurya founder Chandragupta Maurya, to South India to escape the famine.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Meanwhile, another monk, Sthulabhadra (or Sthulabahu), stayed back in North India with a separate group of followers.

During this time, differences emerged in practices and interpretation of Jain teachings.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Bhadrabahu's group continued to follow the strict original practices, including complete renunciation and nudity (Digambara).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Sthulabahu allowed changes, including wearing white clothes, for practical reasons, which became the norm in the North (Swetambara).

**Sects of Jainism**
The two sects of Jainism are Digambaras and Swetambaras. 

**1. Digambaras ("sky-clad"):**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Follow stricter practices.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Practice nudity, especially for monks.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Believe women cannot attain liberation without being reborn as men.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Associated mostly with South India.

**2. Swetambaras ("white-clad"):**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Wear white robes.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Allow both men and women to pursue liberation.
‚ñ™Ô∏è More liberal in rituals and scriptures.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Associated mostly with North India.

blocks.string: Split in Jainism

children.string:
After the death of Mahavira, Jainism expanded widely. To preserve and organize its teachings, two major Jain councils (meetings of monks) were held in ancient India:

**First Jain Council**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Held at: Pataliputra (modern Patna, Bihar)
‚ñ™Ô∏è Time: 3rd century BCE
‚ñ™Ô∏è Presided by: Sthulabhadra
‚ñ™Ô∏è Purpose: To compile and preserve Mahavira‚Äôs teachings orally.

**Second Jain Council**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Held at: Vallabhi (in Gujarat)
‚ñ™Ô∏è Time: 512 AD, during Gupta period in north India. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Presided by: Devardhi Kshemasramana
‚ñ™Ô∏è Purpose: To write down the Jain scriptures (Agamas) in Sanskrit, as the oral tradition was weakening.

blocks.string: Jainism ‚Äì Jain Councils

** Important Rulers Associated with Jainism**

**Bimbisara**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Founder of the Haryanka Dynasty, of the Magadh Empire


**Chandragupta Maurya**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Founder of the Maurya Dynasty
‚ñ™Ô∏è Became a follower of Jainism in his later life
‚ñ™Ô∏è Accompanied Bhadrabahu to South India and spent his final years as a Jain monk at Shravanabelagola

**Ravikirti**
‚ñ™Ô∏è  A court poet of Pulakesin II of the Chalukya dynasty
‚ñ™Ô∏è  Praised Jainism in his works, indicating the religious influence in the Chalukya court

**Founder - Chandragupta Maurya (321 - 297 BC)**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Maurya empire was founded by **Chandragupta Maurya** in around 321 BC.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Chandragupta Maurya established "Maurya empire" by overthrowing Nanda dynasty.
‚ñ™Ô∏è He defeated the Dhanananda, the last ruler of Nanda dynasty.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Chandragupta Maurya was helped by **Chanakya (= Kautilya)**, who was an intelligent and politically astute Brahmin. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è **Patliputra** (present day Patna) was the capital of Maurya empire. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Chanakya had written as book named **Arthashatra**, in Sanskrit, in which he mentioned about the different aspected of the Maurya empire. 

**Chandragupta & Jainism**
‚ñ™Ô∏è According to Jain tradition, Chandragupta Maurya adopted Jainism, abdicated his throne, and traveled to Karnataka (south India), where he died by practicing **Sallekhana** (also called **Santhara**), a ritualistic slow starvation to death. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è He was influenced by the Jain saint Bhadrabahu and spent his final years as an ascetic.

**Bindusara (297 - 273 BC )**
‚ñ™Ô∏è He was son of Chandragupta.
‚ñ™Ô∏è He is also called **Amitraghata** (Slayer of foes) or **Amitrochates** in Greek sources.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Deimachus was a Greek ambassador at his court.
‚ñ™Ô∏è He had appointed his son, Ashoka as the governor of Ujjain.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Bindusara is believed to have extended the Mauryan Empire to Mysore as well.
‚ñ™Ô∏è He was a follower of the **Ajivika sect** (an ancient heterodox tradition, like Buddhism and Jainism).

**Ashoka ( 273 - 232 BC)**
‚ñ™Ô∏è He was son of Bindusara.
‚ñ™Ô∏è He was the greatest ruler of Maurya empire.
‚ñ™Ô∏è His capital was Patliputra (present day Patna)
‚ñ™Ô∏è In 261 BC, he founght the Kaling war, and in which thousands of  people dies, and after this war Ashoke converted to buddhism. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è After this, he stoped fighting wars, and started spreading the message of buddhism all around.


‚ñ™Ô∏è At its zenith, Ashoka‚Äôs empire stretched from Afghanistan in the west to Bangladesh in the east. It covered almost the whole Indian subcontinent except present Kerala and Tamil Nadu, and modern-day Sri Lanka.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2FysWQaPH4Em.png?alt=media&token=bf4dddbf-230c-4a07-9bcd-a5ded0223c7a)

**Ashoka & Kalinga war**
‚ñ™Ô∏èThe Kalinga war was fought in the year 261 BC. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è The Kalinga War was fought between Ashoka, the great Mauryan Emperor, and the ruler of the State of Kalinga.
‚ñ™Ô∏è It was seen as one of the most famous and the bloodiest battles in World history, as thousnds of people died in this war
‚ñ™Ô∏è In the **13th Rock Edict Ashoka** describes about the Kalinga war.

**Ashoka & Buddhism**
‚ñ™Ô∏è After the Kalinga War, Ashoka **embraced Buddhism**.
‚ñ™Ô∏è He gave up further wars, and decided to spread the message of love, peace, and non-violence. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è He converted to Buddhism and convened the **Third Buddhist Council** at Patliputra.
‚ñ™Ô∏è The **Third Buddhist Council** was held in **Pataliputra** (modern-day Patna) in **250 BCE** under the patronage of Emperor Ashoka and presided over by **Moggaliputta Tissa**.
‚ñ™Ô∏è In the Third Buddhist Council **Abhidhamma Pitaka** was compiled, which is about Buddhist philosophy.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Ashoka actively spread the message of Dhamma and even appointed special ministers called Dhamma Mahamatras to propagate it.

The Kalinga War was the pivotal event that led Emperor Ashoka to embrace Buddhism and renounce military conquest, dedicating himself to non-violence and spreading the concept of dharma (righteousness) for the rest of his reign.
((ih01EFHq8))

**Chanakya**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Other names are **Vishnugupta** and **Kautilya**.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Chanakya is also called ‚Äò**Indian Machiavelli**‚Äù.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Teacher of Chandragupta Maurya, who was also his Chief Minister.
‚ñ™Ô∏è He was a teacher and scholar at Taxila. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è He was also a minister in the court of Bindusara.
‚ñ™Ô∏è He is credited to be the master strategist behind the usurping of the Nanda throne and the rise of the Mauryan Empire through his student, Chandragupta.
‚ñ™Ô∏è He wrote **Arthashastra** which mentioned about various aspects of Maurya administration.

children.string:
The disappearance of the Mauryas from the political map of India saw the emergence of many indigenous and foreign rulers, who divided north and south India and ruled over them for nearly five centuries.

![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2FK79SV992c1.png?alt=media&token=d8c9572e-e511-444d-b1b7-acdcf6489a37)

The eclipse of the Kushanas in North India and of the Satavahanas in the Deccan in the 3rd century CE resulted in a period of political disintegration. It paved the way for the emergence of several minor powers and new ruling families. It was against this background the Guptas laid the foundation of the empire. After the Mauryas, Guptas realized the political unification of North India and covered much of the Indian subcontinent. The Gupta Empire stretched across northern, central, and parts of southern India between 320 and 550 CE. This was how the Gupta Empire map looked at the end of the 4th century

blocks.string: **Gupta Empire Map**

children.string:
**Rulers of Gupta Dynasty:**

‚ñ™Ô∏è **Sri Gupta (240‚Äì280 CE):** Founder of the Gupta Empire.
‚ñ™Ô∏è **Ghatotkacha (280‚Äì319 CE):** Son of Sri Gupta; ruled as a minor chief.
‚ñ™Ô∏è **Chandragupta I (319‚Äì335 CE):** Considered the real founder of the Gupta Empire; started the Gupta Era (319 CE); married Kumaradevi, a Lichchhavi princess.
‚ñ™Ô∏è **Samudragupta (335‚Äì375 CE):** Known as the ‚ÄúNapoleon of India‚Äù for his extensive conquests; issued gold coins; promoted art and culture.
‚ñ™Ô∏è **Chandragupta II (Vikramaditya) (375‚Äì415 CE):** Son of Samudragupta; his reign marked the golden age of India; patronized Kalidasa and Aryabhata.
‚ñ™Ô∏è **Kumaragupta I (415‚Äì455 CE):** Founded Nalanda University; maintained the empire‚Äôs prosperity.
‚ñ™Ô∏è **Skandagupta (455‚Äì467 CE):** Last powerful Gupta ruler; repelled Hun invasions.
‚ñ™Ô∏è **Later Gupta Rulers:** Weak successors like Purugupta, Narasimhagupta, and Vishnugupta led to the decline of the empire.

**Sri Gupta**
‚ñ™Ô∏è The founder of the Gupta dynasty was Sri Gupta.
‚ñ™Ô∏è He was succeeded by Ghatotkacha.
‚ñ™Ô∏è These two were called Maharajas.

**Chandragupta I (320 ‚Äì 330 A.D.)**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Chandragupta I and was the first to be called Maharajadhiraja (the great king of kings).
‚ñ™Ô∏è He strengthened his position by a matrimonial alliance with the Licchavis.
‚ñ™Ô∏è He married Kumaradevi, a princess of that family.
‚ñ™Ô∏è The Mehrauli Iron Pillar inscription mentions his extensive conquests.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Chandragupta I is considered to be the first important ruler of the Gupta era which starts with his accession in A.D. 320.

**Samudragupta (330-380 A.D.)**
‚ñ™Ô∏è He was the greatest of the rulers of the Gupta dynasty.
‚ñ™Ô∏è His court poet was Harisena.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Harisena composed the  court Allahabad Pillar inscriptions
‚ñ™Ô∏è The Allahabad Pillar inscriptions provide a detailed account of Samudragupta‚Äôs reign.
‚ñ™Ô∏è He marched against the South Indian monarchs.
‚ñ™Ô∏è He issued gold and silver coins with the legend ‚Äòrestorer of the asvamedha‚Äô.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Because of his military achievements, Samudragupta was hailed as ‚Äò**Indian Napoleon**‚Äô.

**Chandragupta II (380-415 A.D.)**
‚ñ™Ô∏è He was son of Samudragupta
‚ñ™Ô∏è He adopted the title  of "Vikramaditya".
‚ñ™Ô∏è Through matrimonial alliances, he strengthened his political power.
‚ñ™Ô∏è His fought war against the Saka satraps of western India.
‚ñ™Ô∏è After his victory, he performed the horse sacrifice and assumed the title Sakari, meaning, ‚Äòdestroyer of Sakas‚Äô. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è He also called himself ‚ÄòVikramaditya‚Äô.

**Kumaragupta**
Kumaragupta was the son and successor of Chandragupta II.
A number of coins were issued and his inscriptions are found all over the Gupta Empire.
Kumaragupta also performed an asvamedha sacrifice.
Kumaragupta laid the foundation of Nalanda University which emerged as an institution of international reputation.
A powerful wealthy tribe called the ‚ÄòPushyamitras‚Äô defeated the Gupta army at the end of his reign.

**Skandagupta**
A branch of the Huns from Central Asia made attempts to cross the Hindukush mountains and invade India.
Skandagupta who really faced the Hun invasion.
He fought successfully against the Huns and saved the empire.

blocks.string: Rulers of Gupta Dynasty

The Delhi Sultanate marked a significant era in Indian history, lasting from A.D. 1206 to 1526, during which five different dynasties ruled over North India and parts of South India. The Sultanate brought extensive changes in society, administration, and culture.

**üè∞ Dynasties of the Delhi Sultanate (1206‚Äì1526)**

The Delhi Sultanate ruled from 1206 to 1526 and consisted of five major dynasties:
1. Slave (Mamluk) Dynasty ‚Äì 1206‚Äì1290
2. Khalji Dynasty ‚Äì 1290‚Äì1320
3. Tughlaq Dynasty ‚Äì 1320‚Äì1414
4. Sayyid Dynasty ‚Äì 1414‚Äì1451
5. Lodi Dynasty ‚Äì 1451‚Äì1526

Key Point
‚ñ™Ô∏è The first four dynasties (Slave, Khalji, Tughlaq, Sayyid) were Turkish in origin.
‚ñ™Ô∏è The Lodi Dynasty was the only Afghan dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate.

**Delhi Sultanate dynasties and their founders:**
1. Slave (Mamluk) Dynasty (1206‚Äì1290) -- Qutubuddin Aibak
2. Khalji Dynasty (1290‚Äì1320) -- Jalauddin Khilji
3. Tughlaq Dynasty (1320‚Äì1414) -- Giyazuddin Tughlaq
4. Sayyid Dynasty (1414‚Äì1451) -- Khizr Khan
5. Lodi Dynasty (1451‚Äì1526) -- Bulul Lodi

children.string:
‚ñ™Ô∏è After the death of Muhammad Ghori in 1206, Qutbuddin Aibak declared independence and established Slave dynasty. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è He was Turkish in origin. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è He made Lahore his capital. Delhi was then his military center. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è This led to the foundation of the Slave Dynasty.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Slave dynasty is also called as **Mamluk** Dynasty.
‚ñ™Ô∏è It was the first Muslim dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate.

**The Slave Dynasty consisted of three sub-dynasties:**
1. Qutbi Dynasty (1206‚Äì1211), founded by Qutbuddin Aibak.
2. First Ilbari Dynasty (1211‚Äì1266), founded by Iltutmish.
3. Second Ilbari Dynasty (1266‚Äì1290), founded by Balban.

Thus we can say that slave dynasty ruled between 1206 till 1290.
Founded by **Qutbuddin Aibak**, a former slave and trusted general of Muhammad Ghori.

**Qutubuddin Aibak (1206 - 1210)**
‚ñ™Ô∏è He was a slave military general under Mohammad Ghori
‚ñ™Ô∏è After the death of Gohri in 2016, he declared him self as independent, and founded the slave dynasty in 1206.
‚ñ™Ô∏è **Lahore** was his capital.

‚ñ™Ô∏è It was built (both started and completed )by Qutubuddin Aibak at Ajmer

‚ñ™Ô∏è  Iltutmish was the real founder of Delhi Sultanate, as it was Iltutmish who shifted capital from Lahore to Delhi.

children.string:
**Mansabdari System**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Introduced by Mughal Emperor Akbar.
‚ñ™Ô∏è It was a unique administrative and military system that assigned ranks (mansabs) to officials based on their civil and military duties, status, and pay. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è This system integrated the nobility, armed forces, and bureaucracy by using a dual-ranking system of "zat" (personal rank and salary) and "sawar" (cavalry contingent to be maintained). 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Appointments, promotions, and dismissals were all made directly by the emperor, who also determined the rank and responsibilities of each mansabdar.

children.string:
**Brahmo Samaj**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Brahmo sabha was founded in 1828
‚ñ™Ô∏è It was founded by Raja Rammohan Roy, in 1828, in Calcutta.
‚ñ™Ô∏è In 1830 it was renamed as "Brahma Samaj"
‚ñ™Ô∏è Raja Rammohan Roy is also known as Father of Indian Renaissance
‚ñ™Ô∏è Gopal Krishna Gokhale called Raja Rammohan Roy the ‚ÄòFather of Modern India‚Äô.

**Core Ideas of Brahmo Samaj**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Belief in one God (monotheism).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Rejection of idol worship and rituals.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Opposed caste system and social evils (sati, polygamy, child marriage).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Brahmo Samaj played the key role in abolition of Sati in India. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Promoted women‚Äôs education and widow remarriage.

**Influence:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Brahmo Samaj based its ideas on the teachings of the Upanishads.

**Raja Rammohan Roy & Press Freedom**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Raja Rammohan Roy started his first Bengali language weekly newspaper, Sambad Koumudi, in 1918
‚ñ™Ô∏è His newspaper Sambad Koumudi helped people form an opinion about the issues affecting their daily life in British India.
‚ñ™Ô∏è In 1822, Roy published the journal Mirat-ul-Akbar in Persian.
‚ñ™Ô∏è It was Mughal ruler Akbar-II who gave the title of "Raja" to Raja Rammohan Roy.

**Arya Samaj**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Arya Samaj was founded by Swami Dayanand Saraswati in 1875 in Bombay.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Arya Samaj believed in the infallibility of the Vedas. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Arya Samaj gave the slogan ‚ÄúBack to the Vedas‚Äù.

**Core Beliefs:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Monotheism (belief in one God).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Rejection of idol worship, rituals, and priestly dominance.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Condemned caste system based on birth, but supported the caste system by occupation. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Promoted equality of all human beings, including women.

**Social Reforms:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Supported widow remarriage.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Opposed child marriage.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Promoted education for girls and boys alike.

** Educational Work:** 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Established Dayanand Anglo-Vedic (DAV) Schools & Colleges.

**Ramakrishna Mission**
‚ñ™Ô∏è It was founded in 1897 by Swami Vivekananda.
‚ñ™Ô∏è It was founded yo spread the teachings of Ramakrishna Paramhansa, guru of Swami Vivekananda. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è The phrase "service to man is service to God" was coined by Swami Vivekananda

**Teachings and Beliefs**
‚ñ™Ô∏è All religions lead to the same truth.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Service to man is service to God.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Promoted universal brotherhood and tolerance.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Condemned caste system and untouchability.

‚ñ™Ô∏è Improved roads and canals for communication and irrigation.

‚ñ™Ô∏è The Doctrine of Lapse caused widespread resentment.
‚ñ™Ô∏è His policies were a major cause leading to the Revolt of 1857.

children.string:
**Vernacular Press Act, 1778**
‚ñ™Ô∏è It was enacted by Lytton in 1778.
‚ñ™Ô∏è This act banned publications of the vernacular language newspapers (local language newspaper). 
‚ñ™Ô∏è It was repealed by Ripon in 1782.

**Factories Acts:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è First Factories Act, 1881 was passed during the tenure of Lord Ripon
‚ñ™Ô∏è Second Factories Act, 1891 was passed during the tenure of Lord Lansdowne
‚ñ™Ô∏è Third Factories Act, 1911 was passed during the tenure of Lord Hardinge-II

**Factories Act of 1881**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Child labor: Prohibited children under seven from working and limited those between seven and twelve to a maximum of nine hours a day. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Safety: Mandated that dangerous machinery be properly fenced to prevent accidents. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Holidays: Required four holidays per month for children. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Scope: Primarily focused on child labor and safety, and only applied to factories with 100 or more workers.

**Factories Act of 1891**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Child labor: Raised the minimum age for employment to nine years. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Weekly rest: Introduced the concept of a weekly holiday for all workers, not just children. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Working hours: Set a maximum of 11 hours per day for women and applied regulations to adult workers as well. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Scope: Expanded the scope of the previous act by applying it to factories with 50 or more workers and adding new regulations for women and children.

**Factories Act 1911**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Reduced adult working hours to 12 per day (including rest intervals).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Mandated holidays and annual leave.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Improved safety measures, like better machinery guards.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Increased inspector powers and fines for violations.

blocks.string: Connected Blocks

**Revenue Systems During British Rule**
‚ñ™Ô∏è The British introduced different land revenue systems to collect taxes from farmers and increase their income from Indian agriculture.

**1. Permanent Settlement (Zamindari System) ‚Äì 1793**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Introduced by Lord Cornwallis in Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Zamindars were made owners of the land and collected rent from peasants.
‚ñ™Ô∏è The revenue was fixed permanently.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Led to exploitation of peasants and decline in agriculture.

**2. Ryotwari System**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Introduced by Thomas Munro in Madras and Bombay Presidencies.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Revenue was collected directly from the peasants (ryots).
‚ñ™Ô∏è The land ownership was given to the cultivator.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Revenue rates were high and revised periodically, causing hardship to peasants.

**3. Mahalwari System**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Introduced by Holt Mackenzie (1822) and implemented by Lord William Bentinck in North-West Provinces, Punjab, and parts of Central India.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Revenue was collected from the village (mahal) collectively.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Village headmen or landlords represented the village.
**Mahatma Gandhi Important Events:**

**In South Africa (1893‚Äì1914)**

1893:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Gandhi went to South Africa to fight a case of Indian merchant Abdullah Khan, and faced racial discrimination.
‚ñ™Ô∏è On June 7, he was ^^thrown out of a first-class train compartment at Pietermaritzburg^^.

1894:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Founded the ^^Natal Indian Congress^^ to fight for the rights of Indians.

1899:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Formed the ^^Indian Ambulance Corps^^ during the Boer War.

1904:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Started the magazine Indian Opinion and established the Phoenix Farm near Durban.

1906:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Led his ^^first Civil Disobedience Movement^^ (Satyagraha) against the Asiatic Ordinance in Transvaal.

1907:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Continued Satyagraha against the Compulsory Registration Law for Asians, known as the ^^Black Act^^, in Transvaal.

1908:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Was tried and ^^imprisoned for the first time^^ in Johannesburg Jail.

1910:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Founded Tolstoy Farm near Johannesburg, later known as Gandhi Ashram.

1913:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Started ^^Satyagraha against the law that cancelled recognition of non-Christian marriages in Cape Town^^.

1914:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Returned to India and was ^^awarded the Kaisar-i-Hind Medal for his service during the Boer War^^.

**In India (1915‚Äì1930)**

1915:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Returned to India (arrived in Bombay on January 9).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Founded the Satyagraha Ashram at Kocharab near Ahmedabad on May 20. In 1917, the Ashram was shifted to the banks of the Sabarmati River.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Began his all-India tour.

1916:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Delivered a speech at the opening ceremony of Banaras Hindu University (BHU) on February 4.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Did not take part in active politics but attended the Lucknow Session of the Indian National Congress (December 26‚Äì30).
‚ñ™Ô∏è At this session, ^^Raj Kumar Shukla from Bihar requested him to visit Champaran^^.

1917:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Entered active politics with the Champaran campaign to help the indigo farmers of Bihar.
‚ñ™Ô∏è ^^Champaran Satyagraha^^ became his ^^first Civil Disobedience Movement^^ in India.

1918:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Launched the ^^Ahmedabad Mill Strike^^ to support industrial workers in February and used hunger strike as a protest for the first time. It was Gandhis ^^first Hunger Strike^^
‚ñ™Ô∏è In March, led the Kheda Satyagraha for farmers who could not pay rent due to crop failure.
‚ñ™Ô∏è ^^Kheda Satyagraha was his first Non-Cooperation Movement^^.

1919:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Called for ^^Satyagraha against the Rowlatt Act^^ on April 6.
‚ñ™Ô∏è ^^Returned the Kaisar-i-Hind Medal^^ in protest against the Jallianwala Bagh Massacre (April 13).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Elected ^^President of the All India Khilafat Conference^^ in November (Delhi).

1920‚Äì22:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Led the Non-Cooperation and Khilafat Movements (August 1920 ‚Äì February 1922).
Called off the movement on February 12, 1922, after the ^^Chauri-Chaura incident^^ (February 5).
‚ñ™Ô∏è This was the first mass-based political movement under Gandhi.

1924:
‚ñ™Ô∏è ^^Presided over the Belgaum Session^^ of the Indian National Congress ‚Äî the only time he became Congress President.

1925‚Äì27:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Retired temporarily from politics and focused on the constructive programme of the Congress.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Returned to active politics in 1927.

**In India (1930‚Äì1948)**
1930‚Äì34:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Launched the ^^Civil Disobedience Movement^^ with the ^^Dandi March^^ (Salt Satyagraha).
‚ñ™Ô∏è First Phase: March 12, 1930 ‚Äì March 5, 1931.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Signed the ^^Gandhi‚ÄìIrwin Pact^^ on March 5, 1931.
‚ñ™Ô∏è ^^Attended the Second Round Table Conference^^ in London (September 7 ‚Äì December 1, 1931).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Second Phase: January 3, 1932 ‚Äì April 17, 1934.
‚ñ™Ô∏è In 1930, Time magazine named him ‚Äú^^Man of the Year^^.‚Äù
‚ñ™Ô∏è  Mahatma Gandhi founded the ^^All India Anti-Untouchability League^^ in September 1932, which was later renamed the Harijan Sevak Sangh (Servants of Untouchables Society)
1934‚Äì39:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Retired again from active politics and established Sevagram (Wardha Ashram).

1939:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Resumed active politics.

1940‚Äì41:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Launched the ^^Individual Satyagraha Movement^^.

1942:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Started the ^^Quit India Movement^^ with the slogan ‚Äú^^Do or Die^^‚Äù (August 9).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Gandhi and other Congress leaders were arrested.

1942‚Äì44:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Detained at Aga Khan Palace, Pune (August 9, 1942 ‚Äì May 1944).
‚ñ™Ô∏è His wife Kasturba and secretary Mahadev Desai died during this period.
‚ñ™Ô∏è This was his last imprisonment.

1945:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Gandhi‚Äôs influence in the Congress started to decline.

1946:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Tried to stop communal violence in Noakhali (East Bengal) and Calcutta after the Muslim League‚Äôs Direct Action call.

1947:
‚ñ™Ô∏è Distressed by the Partition Plan announced on June 3.
Stayed in Calcutta to stop communal riots and observed silence on India‚Äôs Independence Day (August 15).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Returned to Delhi in September.

1948:
‚ñ™Ô∏è ^^Assassinated by Nathuram Godse^^ on January 30 at Birla House, New Delhi.
His last words were ‚ÄúHey Ram.‚Äù

**Titles and Honorifics of Indian Freedom Leaders**
‚ñ™Ô∏è **Mahatma Gandhi** ‚Äì The title **‚ÄúMahatma‚Äù** (Great Soul) was given to him by **Rabindranath Tagore**.

‚ñ™Ô∏è **Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan** ‚Äì Also known as the **‚ÄúFrontier Gandhi‚Äù** for his non-violent struggle in the North-West Frontier Province (now in Pakistan).

‚ñ™Ô∏è The title **‚ÄúFather of the Nation‚Äù** was given to **Mahatma Gandhi** by **Subhas Chandra Bose** in a 1944 radio address from Singapore.

‚ñ™Ô∏è Gandhi gave the title **‚ÄúMahamana‚Äù** to **Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya** (founder of Banaras Hindu University).

‚ñ™Ô∏è **K. Kelappan** is known as the **‚ÄúKerala Gandhi‚Äù** for his leadership in social reform and the freedom movement in Kerala.
---
‚ñ™Ô∏è **Subhas Chandra Bose** was given the title **‚ÄúNetaji‚Äù** by **Indian soldiers in Germany** (Azad Hind members) in 1942.
-----
‚ñ™Ô∏è **Vallabhbhai Patel** was given the title **‚ÄúSardar‚Äù** (Leader) by **the women of Bardoli** during the Bardoli Satyagraha of 1928.
----
‚ñ™Ô∏è Ishwar Chandra was given the title "**Vidyasagar**" by the Sanskrit College in Calcutta due to his excellent performance in Sanskrit studies and philosophy. The title means "Ocean of Knowledge".

**Coral Reefs:**

**Definition:** 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Massive underwater structures built by colonies of tiny animals called coral polyps (phylum Cnidaria).

**Types:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Fringing reefs: Grow close to shorelines.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Barrier reefs: Separated from land by lagoons (e.g., Great Barrier Reef).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Atolls: Ring-shaped around submerged volcanic islands.

‚ñ™Ô∏è Largest reef system ‚Üí ^^Great Barrier Reef^^, in Eastern Australia (2,300 km long, visible from spac![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2FvUR8zNPmJK.png?alt=media&token=ada02dcd-5229-4530-b527-092c715603e8)e).

**Location: **
‚ñ™Ô∏è Tropical waters (30¬∞N‚Äì30¬∞S), clear, warm (20‚Äì30¬∞C), shallow (<50 m), low nutrients.
**Biodiversity: **
‚ñ™Ô∏è "Rainforests of the sea"; ~25% of all marine species despite covering <0.1% of ocean floor.

**Key Species:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Hard corals (reef builders, calcium carbonate skeletons).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Soft corals, sea fans, sponges.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Fish (parrotfish, clownfish), sharks, turtles, mollusks.

**Symbiosis:** 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Polyps host zooxanthellae (photosynthetic algae) ‚Üí provide 90% energy via sugars; give corals color.

**Formation Process:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Polyps secrete CaCO‚ÇÉ ‚Üí form exoskeletons.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Die ‚Üí leave skeleton; new polyps grow on top.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Over millennia ‚Üí massive reef structures.


**Ecological Roles:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Habitat & nursery for marine life.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Coastal protection (wave energy dissipation).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Carbon sink; support fisheries & tourism.


**Major Threats:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Climate change: Warming ‚Üí coral bleaching (zooxanthellae expulsion).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Ocean acidification: CO‚ÇÇ lowers pH ‚Üí weakens CaCO‚ÇÉ skeletons.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Pollution, overfishing, destructive fishing (dynamite/cyanide).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Physical damage (anchors, tourism).

A collection of billions of stars is called a **galaxy**. 
There are billions of galaxies in the universe, each with different shapes e.g Spiral, Circular etc. 
The galaxy that contains our Sun is called the **Milky Way Galaxy** (or Aakash Ganga).
Milky way galaxy is spiral in shape. 
The Milky Way was discovered by **Galileo**. 
At the center of the Milky Way Galaxy, there is a black hole known as **Sagittarius A**.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FCxY7cDubx3.png?alt=media&token=3f3c7429-b9fa-42a2-b0a7-6f1d3c91bbdc)

The study of the universe is called **Cosmology**. 
The objects in the universe are known as **celestial bodies**. The three main types of celestial bodies are stars, planets, and satellites.
**Stars:** These have their own heat and light, such as the Sun.
**Planets:** These are bodies that revolve around a star, such as Earth.
**Satellites:** These are bodies that revolve around a planet, such as the Moon.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FV729jD2PcN.png?alt=media&token=ca5aea40-bea8-4aaf-a451-6ed28ec32dc0)

**About Sun**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Stars are celestial bodies that produce their own heat (energy) and light. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Our Sun is a star in the Milky Way Galaxy. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Sun is primarily composed of hydrogen (H) and helium (He). 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Inside the Sun, two hydrogen atoms come together and fuse to form helium in a process called **fusion**. This fusion occurs due to the high pressure and temperature in the Sun's core. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è The radiation (heat and light) from the Sun is a result of this fusion of hydrogen atoms into helium. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Sunlight takes approximately 8 minutes to reach the surface of the Earth.
‚ñ™Ô∏è The nearest star to the Sun is called "**Proxima Centauri**".

**About Stars**
‚ñ™Ô∏è A group of stars that forms a recognisable pattern in the night sky is called as **constellation**. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è These patterns are often named after mythological characters, animals, or objects. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è The two major constellations are Ursa Major and Ursa Minor.
‚ñ™Ô∏è **Ursa Major**, also known as the Great Bear, is one of the most well-known constellations. It is visible throughout the year in most of the northern hemisphere. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è **Ursa Minor**, also known as the Little Bear, is another prominent constellation. It includes Polaris, also known as the **North  (Pole)Star**, which is located almost directly above the North Pole.

![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2F2CBFWgQONf.png?alt=media&token=e7903a1f-ed2c-4aeb-80b7-4fd6937f7deb)

children.string:
**Solar System Components**
‚ñ™Ô∏è The Sun and the planets that orbit it form the Solar System. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è There are eight planets that revolve around the Sun in elliptical orbits. 

**The eight planets are: **
‚ñ™Ô∏è Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è The first four planets (Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars) are called terrestrial planets.
‚ñ™Ô∏è The last four (Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune) are known as gas giants or Jovian planets. 

![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2FqBhFui2GBC.png?alt=media&token=c5563c15-cd8e-4648-838f-94050a13d942)

**Asteroids**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Between Mars and Jupiter, there is a region that contains numerous asteroids, known as the **Asteroid Belt**. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è In the Asteroid belt the largest astroid is **Ceres**
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2FMWEFwZSOut.png?alt=media&token=72fb5f05-38d8-4c0d-874b-6f6ddae21a61)

Largest planet: Jupiter
Smallest planet: Mercury
Fastest planet (revolution): Mercury (88 days)
Fastest planet (rotation): Jupiter (9 hours, 55 minutes)
Slowest planet (rotation): Venus (243 days)
Hottest planet: Venus

Size wise (ascending order): Mercury, Mars, Venus, Earth, Neptune, Uranus, Saturn, and Jupiter. Jupiter is the largest planet.

‚ñ™Ô∏è All planets rotate counterclockwise (from top view) or from west to east (side view) except for Venus and Uranus, which rotate clockwise or from east to west. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Earth rotates from west to east, and that is why we feel Sun rises from east and sets in the west.

**Mercury:** 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Mercury is the nearest planet to the Sun. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è It is the fastest planet in terms of revolution around the Sun, taking only 88 days. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è It has no satellites.

**Venus:** 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Venus is the second nearest planet to the Sun after Mercury.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Venus is the hottest planet in the solar system because its atmosphere contains a lot of carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas. 
Venus is also called Earth's twin because it is similar in shape and size to Earth. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è It has no natural satellites. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Uranus and Venus are the only planets that rotate from east to west, while the rest rotate from west to east.
‚ñ™Ô∏è The Venus is slowest (in rotation) planet on the solar system, and thus its day (243 earth day) is longer than it year(225 earth days).

**Earth:** 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Earth is the only planet in the Solar System where life exists. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è It is also called the "Blue Planet" due to its appearance from space. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è It has one satellite, the Moon. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è The earth is 150 million KM away from the Sun.

**Mars:** 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Mars is known as the "Red Planet" because of the presence of iron oxide (rust) in its soil, which gives it its reddish color. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è It is also called as Martian planet.
‚ñ™Ô∏è It has two satellites, Phobos and Deimos. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è The highest peak in the Solar System, Olympus Mons, is present in Mars and is a volcano located on Mars.

**Jupiter:** 
‚ñ™Ô∏è It is the largest planet in the Solar System. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è It has highest number of satellites (92) known natural satellites.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Ganymede is the largest natural satellite of Jupiter as well as in the entire Solar System.
**Saturn:** It has 83 known satellites. Titan is the largest moon of Saturn.

blocks.string: Solar System

children.string:
The Earth revolves around the Sun in an elliptical orbit.
This means that the distance between the Earth and the Sun changes throughout the year. 
Our earth completed one revolution around Sun in **265 days and 6 hours**, and thus after every four years we have one extra day in the month of Feburary and that year is called as **leap year**. 
This revolution of earth around the sun is responsible for the changing seasons.

**Aphelion:** The point in Earth's orbit where it is farthest from the Sun. This occurs around early July 4th each year, and the distance is about 152 million KMs

**Perihelion:** The point in Earth's orbit where it is closest to the Sun. This occurs around early January 3rd each year, and the distance is about 147 million KMs.

On average the earth is 150 million KM away from the Sun.

The earth is tilted by 23.5 degree, and thus due to this tilting of earth on its plane we have the tropic of cancer (23.5 degree N) and tropic of capricorn (23.5 degree S)  latitudes. 
This is because at any time in the year the direct rays of earth falls on any latitude between tropic of cancer and capricorn, and thus the region between To cancer and To capricorn receives highest insolation, and is called as **torrid region**.  
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2F4koIr-UM_T.png?alt=media&token=5ed06617-c314-4c3c-b9bf-a646f5ee4aac)

Latitudes:
90 degree N: North pole
66.5 degree N: Artic Circle
23.5 degree N: tropic of cancer
23.5 degree S: tropic of capricorn
66.5 degree S: Antarctic circle
90 degree S: South pole
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FDQv_j_O8is.png?alt=media&token=21247dfe-35a9-4954-8f43-a9ad92f9546d)

When the Suns rays falls direct on the tropic of cancer, it is called **summer solstice**, and it occurs on June 21, the longest day in the north hemisphere. It is called summer solstice because that time it is summer in norther hemisphere. 
June 21: national Yoga day, Summer Solstice

When the Suns rays falls direct on the tropic of Capricorn, it is called **winter solstice**, and it occurs on Dec 21, the shortest day (longest night) in the north hemisphere.  It is called winter solstice because that time it is winter in northern hemisphere.

When the vertical rays of Sun falls directly over equator it is called **equinox**, and it happens twice, once in March 21-22 (Spring season = Vernal (Spring) Equinox ) and once in Sept 22-23 (autum season = Autumnal (Fall) Equinox ). 
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FxQVW2CaUwz.png?alt=media&token=b9246bbc-e320-4fa6-abd7-a30c221facb7)

The the primary cause of the weathers i.e summer, autumm, winter and sprint is the revolution of earth (as well as the titled nature of the earth.)

blocks.string: Revolution of Earth around Sun

children.string:
The Earth rotates on its axis once approximately every 24 hours. This rotation is from west to east, which is why the Sun appears to rise in the east and set in the west.

**Axial Tilt:** The Earth's axis is tilted at an angle of about 23.5 degrees relative to its orbital plane around the Sun. This tilt remains constant as the Earth orbits the Sun.

**Day and Night Cycle:** The primary cause of day and night is the Earth's rotation. As the Earth rotates, different parts of the surface move into and out of the Sun's light.

blocks.string: Rotation of Earth around its won axis.

children.string:
**About Moon**
‚ñ™Ô∏è The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è It is the fifth largest moon in the Solar System.
‚ñ™Ô∏è It is the largest natural satellite relative to the size of its planet. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è The approximate average distance between the Earth and the Moon is 384,400 kilometers (or 238,855 miles). This is also known as one lunar distance and is the average of the Moon's elliptical orbit, which means the distance varies between its closest point (perigee) and farthest point (apogee)

**Synchronous Rotation:** 
‚ñ™Ô∏è The moon takes the same amount of time to rotate on its axis as it does to orbit the Earth. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è This period is approximately 27.3 days.

**Same Face Always Seen:** 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Because the rotation period and the orbital period are the same, the same side of the Moon always faces the Earth. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è This phenomenon is known as tidal locking.

**New Moon:** 
‚ñ™Ô∏è During the new moon phase, the Moon is positioned between the Earth and the Sun. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è The side of the Moon facing Earth is not illuminated by the Sun, making it invisible in the night sky.

**Full Moon:** 
‚ñ™Ô∏è The full moon phase occurs when the Earth is between the Moon and the Sun. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è The side of the Moon facing Earth is fully illuminated, making it appear as a bright, complete circle.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FXdFuqHlxqI.png?alt=media&token=04135d49-ea22-4b49-b01e-43f25b45cd7d)

**Apogee:** Apogee is the point in the Moon's elliptical orbit where it is farthest from the Earth. At apogee, the Moon appears smaller in the sky.
**Perigee:** Perigee is the point in the Moon's elliptical orbit where it is closest to the Earth. At perigee, the Moon appears larger in the sky.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FBsN_XCpyNM.png?alt=media&token=61ca0632-ef20-4988-981e-844608dff4ce)

**Supermoon:** A supermoon occurs when a full moon or a new moon coincides with perigee, the point at which the Moon is closest to the Earth. This results in the Moon appearing larger and brighter than usual.
**Micromoon:** A micromoon occurs when a full moon or a new moon coincides with apogee, the point at which the Moon is farthest from the Earth. This results in the Moon appearing smaller and dimmer than usual.

children.string:
Venus, the second planet from the Sun with a thick, toxic atmosphere. 
It's often called **Earth's "evil twin"** due to its similar size and rocky composition, but vastly different conditions. Venus experiences a runaway greenhouse effect, making it the **hottest planet in our solar system**, with surface temperatures hot enough to melt lead.

**About Indus River:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è The ancient name of Jhelum was "Sindhu".
‚ñ™Ô∏è It originates from Bokharchu glacier, near Mansarovar lake, in Kailash range, in Karakoram range, Tibet.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Leh city is situated on the bank of Indus. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è From Mansarovar lake, Indus rivers runs southwards, but near the Mt. Naga Parbat, it takes southward direction. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Indus has fiver major tributries i.e Jhelum, Chenab, Rabi, Beas and Satluj.
‚ñ™Ô∏è All the **fiver major tributries** i.e Jhelum, Chenab, Rabi, Beas and Satluj, joins and forms Panjnad, which then merges with Indus at Mithankot. 

![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2Ff-spvR_SaB.png?alt=media&token=b0265180-06d1-4101-9a63-284077719bd6)

**Mention of Indus River in Rig Veda**
‚ñ™Ô∏è The rig veda mentions of the "sapta sindhu" means seven rivers, which are Indus and its tributries. 

**Their Ancient Names  were:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Indus --- Sindhu
‚ñ™Ô∏è Jhelum -- Vitasta
‚ñ™Ô∏è Chenab -- Askini
‚ñ™Ô∏è Ravi -- Purushni or Iravati
‚ñ™Ô∏è Beas -- Bipasa or Vipasa ( B--B)
‚ñ™Ô∏è Satluj -- Shatadru or Shutudri (S--S)
‚ñ™Ô∏è Ghaggar -- Saraswati (it has disappeared)  

![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2Fpm7eDrpsF_.png?alt=media&token=500dbebf-b7d8-45c9-b4f6-4cb898801e15)

**Jhelum river:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è The ancient name of Jhelum was "Vitasta".
‚ñ™Ô∏è It originates from Verinag Spring (in Anantnag district, Jammu & Kashmir), located at the foothills of the Pir Panjal range.
‚ñ™Ô∏è It flows through the Srinagar city.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Important lakes that falls on its course are: Dal lake, Wullar lake, Nigeen lake etc.
--
‚ñ™Ô∏è Wullar lake is the largest fresh water lake of India.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Indias only "Floating Post Office" is in Dal lake. 
((NIwFSRzGw))
![ jhelum river image notes ](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2FMehboobElahi%2Fb-n48EsVMp.png?alt=media&token=9276a452-37bb-46e7-8a58-5014b461236e)

**Chenab river:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è The ancient name of Chenab was "Askini".
‚ñ™Ô∏è It originates from Baralacha pass.

**Ravi river:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è The ancient name of Ravi was "Purushni or Iravati".
‚ñ™Ô∏è It originates from Rhotang pass. (also Beas river)
---
‚ñ™Ô∏è The "Harappa" site was situated on the bank of Ravi river.

**Beas river:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è The ancient name of Beas was "Bipasa".
‚ñ™Ô∏è It originates from Rhotang pass. (also Ravi river)
‚ñ™Ô∏è It merges with Satluj river at Harike, in Punjab, India.
‚ñ™Ô∏è It is the only major tributary of Indus that originates as well as ends within India.

**Satluj river:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è The ancient name of Satluj was "Shutudri".
‚ñ™Ô∏è It originates from Mansarovar lake, in Kailash range in Tibet.
‚ñ™Ô∏è It enters India, Himachal Pradesh, through Shipkla pass. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è It is the only major tributary of Indus, that does not originates from India.

**Shoyk river:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Shyok river is a minor tributary of Indus. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è It originates from Siachen glacier.
‚ñ™Ô∏è It flows through the Nubra valley, Ladakh and finally joins Indus in Gilgit Baldistan. 
----
‚ñ™Ô∏è Other minor tributries of Indus river are Shingo, Suru, Zanskar etc.

**Indus Water Treaty**
‚ñ™Ô∏è It was signed in 1960, between India and Pakistan
‚ñ™Ô∏è It was brokered by World Bank
‚ñ™Ô∏è It divided Indus and its tributries into two groups.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Water of Indus, Jhelum and Chenab were given to Pakistan
‚ñ™Ô∏è Water of Ravi, Beas and Satluj were given to India

**Godavari River:**

‚ñ™Ô∏è Second argest river in South India (after Godavari)

Tributaries:

**Kaveri River:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Originated from: Talakaveri (Brahmagiri Hills), Coorg (Kodagu), Karnataka
‚ñ™Ô∏è Largest tributary: ^^Kabini^^ (joins at Tirumakudal Narsipur)
‚ñ™Ô∏è The Kaveri (Cauvery) River is the ^^only perennial river in peninsular India^^, meaning it has a continuous flow of water year-round. This is because its catchment areas receive rain from both the southwest monsoon and the northeast monsoon

**Freshwater on Earth** 
‚ñ™Ô∏è The Earth is a watery place. About 71% of the Earth's surface is water-covered, while the other 29% consists of continents and islands. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è 96.5% of all the Earth's water is contained within the oceans as saltwater, while the remaining 3.5% is freshwater lakes and frozen water locked up in glaciers and the polar ice caps.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Water also exists in the air as water vapor, in rivers and lakes, in icecaps and glaciers, in the ground as soil moisture and in aquifers. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è The vast majority of water on the Earth's surface is saline water in the oceans. 

‚ñ™Ô∏è Over 68% of the freshwater on Earth is found in icecaps and glaciers
‚ñ™Ô∏è 30 percent is found in groundwater. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Only about 0.3 percent of our freshwater is found in the surface water of lakes, rivers, and swamps. 


‚ñ™Ô∏è The Antarctic ice sheet holds about 90 percent of the fresh water that exists on the Earth‚Äôs surface.
‚ñ™Ô∏è The ice sheet covers approximately 8.7 million square miles. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è The Greenland ice sheet also contains large volumes of fresh water. 
These two ice sheets account for more than 99 percent of the freshwater ice on the planet.


‚ñ™Ô∏è **22 March** is celebrated as the world water day every year.
Greenhouse gases¬†**absorb infrared radiation (net heat energy) emitted from Earth‚Äôs surface and reradiating it back to Earth‚Äôs surface.**

Greenhouse gases are molecules in our atmosphere that absorb heat radiating from Earth‚Äôs surface, preventing it from being emitted into space. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è The most common greenhouse gases are (in order of atmospheric concentration) 
1. Water vapor (H2O), 
2. Carbon dioxide (CO2), 
3. Methane (CH4), 
4. Nitrous oxide (N2O),
5. Ozone (O3) (Atmospheric)
6. Fluorinated Gases:  such as HFCs, PFCs, and sulfur hexafluoride SF6
**In 1992, The Kyoto Protocol**¬†is an international treaty of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) that commits state¬†**parties to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.**

‚ñ™Ô∏è The Kyoto Protocol applied to the ^^seven greenhouse gases^^ listed in Annex A: carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), nitrogen trifluoride (NF3)

**About Oxygen Gas**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Chemical Formula: O‚ÇÇ  
‚ñ™Ô∏è Atomic Number: 8  
‚ñ™Ô∏è Natural Abundance: 21% of Earth's atmosphere by volume; most abundant element in Earth's crust (~46% by mass)  
‚ñ™Ô∏è Physical State: Colorless, odorless, tasteless gas at room temperature  
‚ñ™Ô∏è Allotropes: O‚ÇÇ (diatomic oxygen) and O‚ÇÉ (ozone)  
‚ñ™Ô∏è Role in Life: Essential for aerobic respiration in animals and plants  
‚ñ™Ô∏è Ozone Layer: O‚ÇÉ in stratosphere absorbs harmful UV radiation  
‚ñ™Ô∏è First Aid: Used in hyperbaric oxygen therapy for decompression sickness  
‚ñ™Ô∏è Toxicity: Pure O‚ÇÇ at high pressure causes oxygen toxicity (seizures, lung damage)  
‚ñ™Ô∏è Cycle: Produced by photosynthesis; consumed by respiration and decay
‚ñ™Ô∏è Helps in combustion.

Straits

Definition: A narrow passage of water connecting two larger bodies of water, often critical for maritime trade.
Important Straits:

Gibraltar:

Connects: Atlantic Ocean to Mediterranean Sea.
Location: Between southern Spain and northern Morocco.
Significance: Controls access to the Mediterranean; key for European and African trade routes.


Malacca:

Connects: Indian Ocean to South China Sea (Pacific Ocean).
Location: Between Malay Peninsula and Sumatra (Indonesia).
Significance: One of the busiest shipping lanes, vital for global trade (oil, goods).


Bab-el-Mandeb:

Connects: Red Sea to Gulf of Aden (Indian Ocean).
Location: Between Yemen and Djibouti/Eritrea.
Significance: Critical for oil shipments from the Persian Gulf to Europe via the Suez Canal.


Hormuz:

Connects: Persian Gulf to Gulf of Oman (Indian Ocean).
Location: Between Iran and Oman.
Significance: Major chokepoint for global oil exports (about 20% of world‚Äôs oil passes through).

Isthmus

Definition: A narrow strip of land connecting two larger landmasses, with water on both sides.
Important Isthmuses:

Isthmus of Panama:

Location: Connects North and South America.
Significance: Home to the Panama Canal, linking Atlantic and Pacific Oceans for trade.


Isthmus of Suez:

Location: Connects Africa and Asia (Egypt).
Significance: Site of the Suez Canal, a vital shipping route between Europe and Asia.


Isthmus of Kra:

Location: Southern Thailand, connecting Malay Peninsula to mainland Asia.
Significance: Potential site for a canal to shorten maritime routes in Southeast Asia.

**Types of economic systems**

**Closed or Command Economy: **
‚ñ™Ô∏è The government owns and controls the means of production and makes all economic decisions.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Features: Centralized planning, state ownership of industry, and lack of private sector competition.

**Open or Market Economy: **
‚ñ™Ô∏è Relies on private ownership and free markets, where supply and demand determine prices and production.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Features: Minimal government intervention, private property rights, and competition. 

**Mixed Economy: **
‚ñ™Ô∏è Blends aspects of both market and command economies, allowing for both private enterprise and government intervention.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Features: Coexistence of public and private sectors; government regulates industries and provides social welfare programs.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Example: India, which has private companies in many sectors but also state-owned enterprises for services like defense and energy, according to 5paisa.

**RBI (Reserve Bank of India)**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Founded April 1, 1935, under RBI Act 1934; 
‚ñ™Ô∏è HQ in Mumbai (shifted from Kolkata in 1937); 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Nationalized in 1949.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Current Governor: Sanjay Malhotra (appointed Dec 2024; oversees monetary policy & banking regs).

**Core Functions:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Issue & manage currency (regulates money supply).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Formulate & implement monetary policy (e.g., repo rate, CRR, SLR to control inflation & growth).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Banker to govt (manages public debt, accounts).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Regulator of banks & NBFCs
‚ñ™Ô∏è Forex management
‚ñ™Ô∏è Promotes financial inclusion 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Bank of last resort for bankers

**SEBI (Securities & Exchange Board of India)**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Set up Apr 12, 1988 (statutory powers via SEBI Act 1992); 
‚ñ™Ô∏è HQ in Mumbai; 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Under Ministry of Finance.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Current Chairman: Tuhin Kanta Pandey.


**Core Functions:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Regulate stock exchanges, brokers, mutual funds, depositories.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Prevent unfair practices (insider trading, fraud).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Promote investor education & market development.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Ensure transparency in disclosures & listings.

**Economic Fullforms:**

**Important Full Forms In Economy:** 
**IBPS:** Institute of Banking Personnel Selection	
Conducts recruitment exams for bank jobs (PO, Clerk, SO).

**SBI:** State Bank of India	
Largest public sector bank; key player in Indian banking sector.

**UPI:**	Unified Payments Interface	
Digital payment system enabling instant money transfer.

**RBI:**	Reserve Bank of India	
India's central banking institution; regulates monetary policy.

**SEBI:** Security Exchange Board of India
Regulates security market and stock exchanges in India

**ATM:** Automated Teller Machine	
Self-service banking for withdrawals and other services.

**CRR:** Cash Reserve Ratio

**Goods and Service Tax (GST)**
‚ñ™Ô∏è It is an indirect tax used in India on the supply of goods and services.
‚ñ™Ô∏è It is a value-added tax levied on most goods and services sold for domestic consumption.
‚ñ™Ô∏è It was launched in India on 1 July 2017 as a comprehensive indirect tax for the entire country.
‚ñ™Ô∏è It is a comprehensive, multistage, destination-based tax comprehensive because it has subsumed almost all the indirect taxes except a few state taxes. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è It is paid by the consumers and is remitted to the government by the businesses selling the goods and services.

‚ñ™Ô∏è It is of three types i.e.
‚ñ™Ô∏è 1. CGST to be levied by the Centre, 
‚ñ™Ô∏è 2. SGST to be levied by the States and 
‚ñ™Ô∏è 3. IGST is a tax levied on all Inter-State supplies of goods and/or services.  

‚ñ™Ô∏è All these taxes are levied at rates mutually agreed upon by the Centre and the States. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è The GST Council headed by the Union Finance Minister is the governing and key decision-making body for GST.

**The following items are not covered under GST:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Petrol, high-speed diesel, aviation turbine fuel, crude oil.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Electricity
‚ñ™Ô∏è Alcohol used for human consumption

‚ñ™Ô∏è The State Emblem of India is an adaptation of the Lion Capital of Ashoka at Sarnath.
‚ñ™Ô∏è It was erected by Ashoka at Sarnath in around 250BC
‚ñ™Ô∏è Adopted on 26 January 1950 (the day India became a Republic).
‚ñ™Ô∏è It consists of four Asiatic lions standing back-to-back.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Out of four lions, only three are visible (the fourth is hidden).

Below the lions, there is a circular base featuring:
A horse on the left.
A bull on the right.
The Dharma Chakra (wheel) in the center.
An elephant and a lion carved on the abacus.

The motto inscribed below in Devanagari script:
‚ÄúSatyameva Jayate‚Äù (Truth Alone Triumphs) ‚Äî taken from the Mundaka Upanishad.

It is used on all official documents, currency notes, passports, and government buildings.

**Plant vs Animal Cells**
**Plant Cells**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Cell Wall: A rigid outer layer (made of cellulose) that provides structural support and protection.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Chloroplasts: Organelles containing chlorophyll that are responsible for photosynthesis.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Large Central Vacuole: A large, fluid-filled sac that helps maintain turgor pressure and stores water and nutrients.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Shape: Generally regular, fixed, and rectangular or cube-shaped.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Centrioles: Absent.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Lysosomes: Rare or absent. 

**Animal Cells**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Cell Wall: Absent; has a flexible plasma membrane instead.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Chloroplasts: Absent; animal cells must obtain energy from food sources.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Vacuoles: Present but small and scattered.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Shape: Irregular and flexible.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Centrioles: Present; involved in cell division.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Lysosomes: Present; contain digestive enzymes.

**DNA vs RNA**
**DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Double-stranded helix.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Contains deoxyribose sugar.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Nitrogen bases: Adenine (A), Thymine (T), Cytosine (C), Guanine (G).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Found mostly in the nucleus.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Function: Stores genetic information.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Stable and long-lasting molecule.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Replicates itself during cell division.

**RNA (Ribonucleic Acid)**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Single-stranded molecule.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Contains ribose sugar.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Nitrogen bases: Adenine (A), Uracil (U), Cytosine (C), Guanine (G) ‚Äî Uracil replaces Thymine.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Found in nucleus and cytoplasm.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Function: Helps in protein synthesis.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Less stable and short-lived.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Formed from DNA through transcription.

**Key Differences**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Sugar: DNA ‚Üí Deoxyribose | RNA ‚Üí Ribose
‚ñ™Ô∏è Bases: DNA ‚Üí Thymine | RNA ‚Üí Uracil
‚ñ™Ô∏è Strands: DNA ‚Üí Double | RNA ‚Üí Single
‚ñ™Ô∏è Function: DNA ‚Üí Genetic code | RNA ‚Üí Protein synthesis

**Nitrogen Fixation**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Definition: The process of converting atmospheric nitrogen (N‚ÇÇ) into usable nitrogen compounds like ammonia (NH‚ÇÉ), nitrates, or nitrites that plants can absorb.

**Types of Nitrogen Fixation**
**Biological Nitrogen Fixation:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Done by bacteria and cyanobacteria (blue-green algae).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Example: Rhizobium bacteria in root nodules of leguminous plants (peas, beans, lentils).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Enzyme involved: Nitrogenase.

**Industrial Nitrogen Fixation:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Done by the Haber-Bosch process, which converts N‚ÇÇ and H‚ÇÇ into ammonia under high pressure and temperature.

**Atmospheric Nitrogen Fixation:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Occurs naturally during lightning, when high energy converts N‚ÇÇ and O‚ÇÇ into nitrates that mix with rainwater and enter the soil.

**Nuclear Fission**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Definition: Splitting of a heavy nucleus into two or more lighter nuclei.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Example: Uranium-235 or Plutonium-239 fission.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Process: Neutron hits the nucleus ‚Üí nucleus splits ‚Üí releases energy + more neutrons.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Energy Output: Large amount, but less than fusion.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Chain Reaction: Released neutrons can cause further fission reactions.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used in: Nuclear power plants, atomic bombs.
‚ñ™Ô∏è By-products: Radioactive waste.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Condition: Can occur at ordinary temperatures once initiated.

**Nuclear Fusion**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Definition: Joining (fusion) of two light nuclei to form a heavier nucleus.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Example: Hydrogen isotopes (Deuterium + Tritium) ‚Üí Helium.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Process: Extremely high temperature and pressure needed (as in stars).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Energy Output: Much greater than fission.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used in: ^^Hydrogen bombs^^, occurs ^^naturally in the Sun and stars^^.
‚ñ™Ô∏è By-products: Less radioactive waste.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Condition: Requires millions of degrees of temperature

**‚öõÔ∏è About Atom**

‚ñ™Ô∏è An **atom** is the **smallest unit of matter** that retains the properties of an element.
‚ñ™Ô∏è The concept of the atom was first proposed by **John Dalton (1808)** in his **Atomic Theory**.

**Structure of Atom:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è An atom consists of **three subatomic particles** ‚Äî **Electrons, Protons, and Neutrons**.

**Basic Composition:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è **Nucleus:** Contains **protons** (positively charged) and **neutrons** (neutral).
‚ñ™Ô∏è * **Shells/Orbits:** Contain **electrons** (negatively charged) revolving around the nucleus.

**Subatomic Particles:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è **Electron (e‚Åª):** Discovered by **J.J. Thomson** (1897).
‚ñ™Ô∏è **Proton (p‚Å∫):** Discovered by **Ernest Rutherford** (1919).
‚ñ™Ô∏è **Neutron (n‚Å∞):** Discovered by **James Chadwick** (1932).

**Charges:**
‚ñ™Ô∏èProton ‚Üí **Positive (+1)**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Electron ‚Üí **Negative (‚àí1)**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Neutron ‚Üí **Neutral (0)**

**Mass Distribution:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Almost all atomic mass is concentrated in the **nucleus** (protons + neutrons).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Electrons have negligible mass.

‚ñ™Ô∏è **Atomic Number (Z):** Number of **protons** in an atom.
‚ñ™Ô∏è **Mass Number (A):** Total number of **protons + neutrons** in an atom.

**Examples:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Hydrogen ‚Üí 1 proton, 0 neutron, 1 electron.
‚ñ™Ô∏è Helium ‚Üí 2 protons, 2 neutrons, 2 electrons.

**Input & Output Devices**

**Input Devices**

**Output Devices**

**Examples:**

**What is Computer Memory?**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Technology for temporary or permanent data storage
‚ñ™Ô∏è Uses binary (0 and 1)
‚ñ™Ô∏è Allows saving and accessing data as needed

**Types of Memory**
**Primary Memory (Main/Internal Memory)**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Built-in, faster, limited capacity
‚ñ™Ô∏è Volatile (except ROM)
‚ñ™Ô∏è Uses semiconductor technology
‚ñ™Ô∏è Essential for processing

**1. RAM (Random Access Memory) - **
‚ñ™Ô∏è Read-Write, Volatile
‚ñ™Ô∏è Stores data/programs during execution
‚ñ™Ô∏è Lost on power off
‚ñ™Ô∏è Boosts system speed

**2. ROM (Read-Only Memory) **
‚ñ™Ô∏è Non-Volatile
‚ñ™Ô∏è Stores permanent data (e.g., boot instructions)
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used in embedded systems, peripherals
‚ñ™Ô∏è Simple, reliable, no refresh


**Secondary Memory (External Storage)**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Non-volatile, large capacity, slower
‚ñ™Ô∏è Retains data after power off

**Types:**
**Solid-State (e.g., SSD, USB)**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Uses microchips
‚ñ™Ô∏è Fast, durable, no moving parts


**Magnetic (e.g., HDD)**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Hard Dist Drive (HDD)
‚ñ™Ô∏è Uses spinning disks + magnetic fields
‚ñ™Ô∏è High capacity, cheaper per GB


**Optical (e.g., CD, DVD, Blu-ray)**
‚ñ™Ô∏è CD: Compact Disc
‚ñ™Ô∏è DVD: Digital Versatile Disc
‚ñ™Ô∏è Uses laser to read pits/lands
‚ñ™Ô∏è Portable, low cost



**Primary Memory**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Fast, essential for CPU
‚ñ™Ô∏è Limited space, costly

**Secondary Memory**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Large capacity, permanent storage
‚ñ™Ô∏è Slower access, not directly used by CPU

children.string:
2. Nobody ‚Üí Nothing
Rule: Use "nothing" for objects or things when the subject is "nobody".
Example:
Nobody found nothing interesting in the movie.
(No person found any interesting thing.)
3. Somebody ‚Üí Something
Rule: Use "something" for objects or things when the subject is "somebody".
Example:
Somebody brought something for you.
(A person brought an item for you.)
4. Anybody ‚Üí Anything
Rule: Use "anything" for objects or things when the subject is "anybody".
Example:
Anybody can do anything if they try hard.
(Any person can accomplish any task.)
Key Points:
"Everybody," "Nobody," "Somebody," "Anybody" ‚Üí refer to people.
"Everything," "Nothing," "Something," "Anything" ‚Üí refer to things or objects.

Practise vs Practice
Practise (Verb): To do something repeatedly to improve.
Example: You should practise batting daily.
Practice (Noun): The act of doing something regularly.
Example: Cricket practice starts at 6 AM.

**Advice vs Advise**
Advice (Noun): Suggestion or recommendation.
Example: His advice helped me score a century.
Advise (Verb): To give suggestion.
Example: The coach advised him to play defensively.

Complain vs Complaint
Complain (Verb): To express dissatisfaction.
Example: Fans complain about poor umpiring.
Complaint (Noun): A statement of dissatisfaction.
Example: He filed a complaint against the decision.

Affect vs Effect
Affect (Verb): To influence.
Example: Rain affected the match.
Effect (Noun/Verb): Result / To bring about.
Example: The effect was a draw.

**Assure vs Ensure vs Insure**
Assure (Verb): To promise or reassure.
Example: He assured the team of victory.
Ensure (Verb): To make certain.
Example: Ensure you wear helmet.
Insure (Verb): To protect financially (insurance).
Example: Insure your bat against damage.

Hear vs Listen
Hear (Verb): To perceive sound.
Example: I heard the crowd cheer.
Listen (Verb): To pay attention to sound.
Example: Listen to the coach carefully.

Heal vs Heel
Heal (Verb): To cure or recover.
Example: The injury will heal in a week.
Heel (Noun): Back part of foot.
Example: He was hit on the heel.

Prescribe vs Proscribe
Prescribe (Verb): To recommend (medicine).
Example: Doctor prescribed rest.
Proscribe (Verb): To prohibit.
Example: Betting is proscribed in cricket.

Adopt vs Adapt vs Adept
Adopt (Verb): To take up legally.
Example: They adopt new batting technique.
Adapt (Verb): To adjust.
Example: Adapt to spin bowling.
Adept (Adjective): Skilled.
Example: He is adept at cover drive.

Allude vs Elude
Allude (Verb): To refer indirectly.
Example: He alluded to his century.
Elude (Verb): To escape.
Example: The ball eluded the fielder.

Amend vs Emend
Amend (Verb): To improve or change (law).
Example: They amended the playing rules.
Emend (Verb): To correct (text).
Example: The scorecard was emended.

Bought vs Brought
Bought (V. of buy): Purchased.
Example: He bought a new bat.
Brought (V. of bring): Carried.
Example: He brought lunch to the ground.

Compose vs Comprise
Compose (Verb): To make up.
Example: The team is composed of 11 players.
Comprise (Verb): To include.
Example: The team comprises 11 players.

Deface vs Efface
Deface (Verb): To spoil appearance.
Example: Someone defaced the stadium wall.
Efface (Verb): To erase.
Example: He effaced the mistake from the board.

Deprecate vs Depreciate
Deprecate (Verb): To disapprove.
Example: He deprecated sledging.
Depreciate (Verb): To reduce in value.
Example: Old bats depreciate fast.

Envelop vs Envelope
Envelop (Verb): To wrap or cover.
Example: Fog enveloped the stadium.
Envelope (Noun): Paper cover.
Example: Put the ticket in an envelope.

Excite vs Incite
Excite (Verb): To arouse interest.
Example: The match excited the crowd.
Incite (Verb): To provoke.
Example: He incited the fans to boo.

Flout vs Flaunt
Flout (Verb): To disobey openly.
Example: He flouted the no-ball rule.
Flaunt (Verb): To show off.
Example: He flaunted his new bat.

Hoard vs Horde
Hoard (Verb/Noun): To store secretly.
Example: He hoards old cricket balls.
Horde (Noun): Large group.
Example: A horde of fans rushed in.

Loathe vs Loath
Loathe (Verb): To hate.
Example: I loathe losing.
Loath (Adjective): Reluctant.
Example: He is loath to bowl in death overs.

Lose vs Loose
Lose (Verb): To misplace or fail.
Example: Don't lose the match.
Loose (Adjective): Not tight.
Example: His grip was loose.

Mitigate vs Militate
Mitigate (Verb): To lessen.
Example: Rain gear mitigates discomfort.
Militate (Verb): To oppose (with against).
Example: Injury militates against performance.

Pour vs Pore
Pour (Verb): To flow.
Example: Rain poured during the match.
Pore (Verb): To study closely.
Example: He pored over the scorecard.

Proceed vs Precede
Proceed (Verb): To continue.
Example: Proceed to the next over.
Precede (Verb): To come before.
Example: Warm-up precedes the match.

Pray vs Prey
Pray (Verb): To request spiritually.
Example: Fans pray for victory.
Prey (Noun/Verb): Victim / To hunt.
Example: Bowlers prey on weak batsmen.

Rout vs Route
Rout (Verb/Noun): Defeat badly.
Example: India routed Australia.
Route (Noun): Path.
Example: The team took a new route to the stadium.

Censor vs Censure
Censor (Verb): To suppress content.
Example: They censored the controversial ad.
Censure (Verb): To criticize strongly.
Example: The board censured the player.

Wave vs Waive
Wave (Noun/Verb): Hand gesture / Ocean movement.
Example: Fans wave flags.
Waive (Verb): To give up right.
Example: He waived the follow-on.

Tow vs Toe
Tow (Verb/Noun): To pull.
Example: The car was towed away.
Toe (Noun): Part of foot.
Example: He stepped on my toe.

Site vs Sight vs Cite
Site (Noun): Location.
Example: The match site was changed.
Sight (Noun): Vision.
Example: The six was a beautiful sight.
Cite (Verb): To quote.
Example: He cited the rule correctly.

Diffuse vs Defuse
Diffuse (Verb): To spread.
Example: Rumors diffused quickly.
Defuse (Verb): To calm tension.
Example: Captain defused the argument.

Desert vs Dessert
Desert (Noun/Verb): Sandy area / To abandon.
Example: He deserted the team.
Dessert (Noun): Sweet dish.
Example: Ice cream is a popular dessert.

Sever vs Severe
Sever (Verb): To cut off.
Example: He severed ties with the coach.
Severe (Adjective): Serious.
Example: The injury was severe.

See vs Look vs Stare vs Peep vs Glare vs Glow vs Glance vs Glimpse
See (Verb): To perceive with eyes.
Example: I saw the ball hit the stump.
Look (Verb): To direct gaze.
Example: Look at the scoreboard.

Stare (Verb): To gaze fixedly.
Example: He stared at the umpire.
Peep (Verb): To look secretly.
Example: He peeped through the window.

Glare (Verb/Noun): Angry look / Bright light.
Example: He glared at the bowler.
Glow (Verb/Noun): Soft light.
Example: The trophy glowed in the light.

Glance (Verb/Noun): Quick look.
Example: He glanced at the clock.
Glimpse (Noun/Verb): Brief view.
Example: I caught a glimpse of the captain.

Light vs Burn
Light (Noun/Verb/Adjective): Illumination / Not heavy.
Example: The stadium lights were bright.
Burn (Verb/Noun): To be on fire.
Example: The sun burned his skin.

Catch vs Hold
Catch (Verb/Noun): To grab in air.
Example: He took a brilliant catch.
Hold (Verb/Noun): To grip.
Example: Hold the bat firmly.

Canvas vs Canvass
Canvas (Noun): Cloth.
Example: The banner was made of canvas.
Canvass (Verb): To campaign.
Example: They canvassed for fan support.

Refuse vs Deny vs Decline
Refuse (Verb): To reject.
Example: He refused to play.
Deny (Verb): To say not true.
Example: He denied cheating.
Decline (Verb): To refuse politely.
Example: He declined the interview.

Peddle vs Pedal
Peddle (Verb): To sell (illegally).
Example: He peddled fake tickets.
Pedal (Noun/Verb): Foot lever / To ride cycle.
Example: He pressed the pedal hard.

Ride vs Drive
Ride (Verb/Noun): To sit on and control (horse/bike).
Example: He rides a bike to the ground.
Drive (Verb/Noun): To operate (car).
Example: He drives the team bus.

Wither vs Weather vs Whether
Wither (Verb): To dry up.
Example: The grass withered in heat.
Weather (Noun/Verb): Climate / To survive.
Example: The match weathered the storm.
Whether (Conjunction): If.
Example: Whether we win or lose...

Sink vs Drown
Sink (Verb): To go down in water.
Example: The ball sank in the lake.
Drown (Verb): To die in water.
Example: He nearly drowned in the pool.

Cease vs Seize
Cease (Verb): To stop.
Example: Play ceased due to rain.
Seize (Verb): To grab.
Example: Police seized fake tickets.

Invent vs Discover
Invent (Verb): To create something new.
Example: He invented a new bat grip.
Discover (Verb): To find something existing.
Example: He discovered a talent in bowling.

**Simple Present Tense**
Active Form:
Subject + V¬π(s/es) + Object

Passive Form:
Object + is/am/are + V¬≥ (past participle) + by + Subject

Example:
Active: She writes a letter.
Passive: A letter is written by her.

**Present Continuous Tense**

Active Form:
Subject + is/am/are + V¬π + ing + Object

Passive Form:
Object + is/am/are + being + V¬≥ + by + Subject

Example:
Active: He is painting the wall.
Passive: The wall is being painted by him.

**Present Perfect Tense**

Active Form:
Subject + has/have + V¬≥ + Object

Passive Form:
Object + has/have + been + V¬≥ + by + Subject

Example:
Active: They have completed the work.
Passive: The work has been completed by them.

children.string:
**Simple Past Tense**

Active Form:
Subject + V¬≤ + Object

Passive Form:
Object + was/were + V¬≥ + by + Subject

Example:
Active: She wrote a letter.
Passive: A letter was written by her.

**Past Continuous Tense**

Active Form:
Subject + was/were + V¬π + ing + Object

Passive Form:
Object + was/were + being + V¬≥ + by + Subject

Example:
Active: He was cleaning the room.
Passive: The room was being cleaned by him.

**Past Perfect Tense**

Active Form:
Subject + had + V¬≥ + Object

Passive Form:
Object + had + been + V¬≥ + by + Subject

Example:
Active: They had finished the project.
Passive: The project had been finished by them.

children.string:
**Simple Future Tense**

Active Form:
Subject + will/shall + V¬π + Object

Passive Form:
Object + will/shall + be + V¬≥ + by + Subject

Example:
Active: She will cook the food.
Passive: The food will be cooked by her.

**Future Perfect Tense**

Active Form:
Subject + will/shall + have + V¬≥ + Object

Passive Form:
Object + will/shall + have been + V¬≥ + by + Subject

Example:
Active: They will have built a bridge.
Passive: A bridge will have been built by them.

blocks.string: Imperative Sentence

**Passive of Sentences starting with "Let"**
Watch: {video:OXTMldnx7Y0:0}  

Rule 1: When one Object is there:
Let + O1 + V1 

Passive:
(a) It is suggested that + Sub + V1
(b) Let + O + "be allowed to" + V1

Rule 2: When there are 2 Objects
Let + O1 + V1 + O2

Passive:
Let + O2 + be + V3 + by + O1

**Active Passive of Infinitive Sentences (to + V1)**
Watch: {video:5aV30Lieh0A:0} 

Active: 
Sub + Hv + to + V1 + Obj

Passive:
Obj + Hv + to + be + V3 + by + Sub

**Imperative Sentences (Commands / Requests)**
Rule:
Let + Object + be + V¬≥ (past participle)

Examples:
Active: Let him do the work.
Passive: Let the work be done by him.

Active: Let them finish the task.
Passive: Let the task be finished by them.

**If ‚ÄúLet‚Äù Expresses Permission or Suggestion**
Rule:
Let + (person) + be + allowed / permitted + to + V¬π

Examples:
Active: Let him go now.
Passive: Let him be allowed to go now.

Active: Let the students enter the hall.
Passive: Let the students be permitted to enter the hall.

**For ‚ÄúLet Us‚Äù Sentences (Suggestions / Proposals)**
Rule:
Let us + V¬π ‚Üí It is suggested / proposed that + we should + V¬π

Examples:
Active: Let us start our journey.
Passive: It is suggested that our journey should be started.

Active: Let us respect our elders.
Passive: It is proposed that our elders should be respected.

**Rules for Active Passive**

Use of Articles: A, An, and The

**A:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used before singular countable nouns that begin with a consonant sound (e.g., a boy, a car, a teacher).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used when referring to something for the first time (e.g., I saw a dog).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used to show one of many (e.g., a student in the class).

**AN:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used before singular countable nouns that begin with a vowel sound (a, e, i, o, u) (e.g., an apple, an egg, an umbrella).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Also used before silent 'h' words (e.g., an hour, an honest man).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used when referring to something for the first time and pronunciation starts with a vowel sound (e.g., an MLA, an MBA).The correct article to complete the sentence is an:
He is an honest man.
Explanation of the Article "An"
Even though the word "honest" begins with the consonant letter 'h', the rule for using "a" or "an" is based on the sound of the first letter. In "honest," the 'h' is silent, and the word starts with a vowel sound (the 'o' sound). 
An is used before words that start with a vowel sound.
A is used before words that start with a consonant sound.

**THE:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used to refer to something specific or already known (e.g., the book on the table).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used before unique things (e.g., the sun, the moon, the Earth).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used before superlatives (e.g., the best, the tallest).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used before names of rivers, seas, oceans, and mountain ranges (e.g., the Ganga, the Pacific Ocean, the Himalayas).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used before well-known institutions or monuments (e.g., the Taj Mahal, the Parliament).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used before ordinal numbers (e.g., the first, the second).

**Common examples and usage**
**Time:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è For: shows duration (e.g., "for two hours"). 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Since: shows a starting point (e.g., "since morning"). 
‚ñ™Ô∏è At: is for specific points (e.g., "at 3 PM"). 
‚ñ™Ô∏è On: is for days and dates (e.g., "on Monday," "on December 25th"). 
‚ñ™Ô∏è In: is for longer periods, like months, years, and seasons (e.g., "in July," "in 2025"). 

**Place:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è In: for larger places (e.g., "in London"). 
‚ñ™Ô∏è At: for specific points (e.g., "at the station"). 
‚ñ™Ô∏è On: for surfaces (e.g., "on the table"). 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Under, over, across, through: Indicate location relative to another object. 

**Direction:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Into: to show movement to the inside of something (e.g., "jumped into the river"). 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Towards: to show a particular direction (e.g., "glanced towards the mirror"). 
‚ñ™Ô∏è From: to show the source or origin (e.g., "took my driving license from me").

**Important notes**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Always has an object: A preposition is always followed by a noun or pronoun. 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Avoid extra prepositions: Don't use redundant prepositions. For example, say "enter the room," not "enter into the room". 
‚ñ™Ô∏è Ending sentences: While ending a sentence with a preposition is acceptable in informal English, it is best to avoid in formal writing (e.g., informally, "Who are you talking to?"; formally, "To whom are you talking?").

**Prepositions: ON, IN, and AT**

**ON:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used for days and dates (e.g., on Monday, on 26th January).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used when something is touching a surface (e.g., on the table, on the wall).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used for devices and technology (e.g., on TV, on the phone, on the computer).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used for public transport (e.g., on the bus, on a plane).


**IN:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used for months, years, and centuries (e.g., in July, in 2020, in the 18th century).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used to show enclosed spaces or areas (e.g., in a room, in the box, in India).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used to express time periods (e.g., in the morning, in two hours).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used for fields of work or study (e.g., in medicine, in education).


**AT:**
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used for specific time (e.g., at 5 o‚Äôclock, at midnight).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used for specific places or points (e.g., at the door, at the bus stop, at home).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used for events or locations of activities (e.g., at the party, at school).
‚ñ™Ô∏è Used for addresses (e.g., at 25 MG Road).
